item.title: David Sacks is Trump’s AI and crypto ‘czar’
item.description:
President-elect Donald Trump says that VC and All-In podcast co-host David Sacks will be the “White House A.I. & Crypto Czar.”

The appointment of Sacks, who hosted a $300,000-a-person dinner at his San Francisco mansion to fundraise for Trump’s campaign, follows the appointment of fellow PayPal mafia member Elon Musk to co-lead the “Department of Government Efficiency.” According to Bloomberg, like Musk, Sacks will be “a special government employee” who can serve up to 130 days a year without divesting or publicly disclosing his assets.

Here’s what Sacks will be tasked with in his role, according to Trump:

In this important role, David will guide policy for the Administration in Artificial Intelligence and Cryptocurrency, two areas critical to the future of American competitiveness. David will focus on making America the clear global leader in both areas. He will safeguard Free Speech online, and steer us away from Big Tech bias and censorship. He will work on a legal framework so the Crypto industry has the clarity it has been asking for, and can thrive in the U.S.

Trump says Sacks will also head up the Presidential Council of Advisors for Science and Technology, an independent advisory committee that exists today. In a second Truth Social post, Trump highlighted Sacks’ history at PayPal (where he worked with Musk) and his founding of Yammer, which Microsoft bought for $1.2 billion in 2012.

Sacks is a vocal, longtime supporter of Musk. He’s an investor in SpaceX and played a key role in Musk’s takeover of Twitter. His VC firm, Craft Ventures, has backed tech firms like the AI enterprise startup Glean and Palantir, the Peter Thiel-founded government contractor. Sacks has also become an influential figure in the Republican Party. He spoke at the 2024 Republican National Convention and was at Mar-a-Lago on Election Day.

Shortly after Trump announced his appointment, leaders from key AI and crypto companies, including OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, rushed to X to congratulate Sacks. “Great pick,” wrote Coinbase COO Emilie Choi. “@DavidSacks was in crypto early and has a nuanced understanding of the space. Time to build in the US!”

Update, December 5th: Added more info about Sacks and responses from tech leaders.
item.dc:creator: Jay Peters

item.title: Thousands flee Syrian city Homs as rebels advance further
item.description: Homs is the next city south on the road from Aleppo to Damascus, which the rebels have vowed to reach.

item.title: S Korea president ordered arrest of own party leader
item.description: The head of President Yoon's party called for his suspension in a sign it may back moves to impeach him.

item.title: Biden considering pre-emptive pardons for Trump critics - sources
item.description: The outgoing president is reported to be weighing up ways to protect those the new administration may go after.

item.title: Moment former Syrian president's statue toppled in Hama
item.description: Rebels say they have taken full control of a second major city, after the military withdrew its troops.

item.title: Amid Middle East Tensions, Iran Launches Heaviest Space Payload Into Orbit
item.description: Iran successfully launched on Friday its heaviest space payload, which includes a satellite and a space tug, using a domestically developed satellite carrier, official media reported.

item.title: How A Dior Handbag Caused One Of South Korea's Biggest Political Scandals
item.description: Amid talks of his impeachment, South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol is battling a series of blunders, including the brief but controversial imposition of martial law, to save his political career.

item.title: Reviled South Korean President Still Likely To Survive Impeachment
item.description: The conservative party of embattled South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol faces a quandary: How do members distance themselves from an unpopular leader without handing a big win to their political opponents.

item.title: Former Pakistan PM Imran Khan, Party Leaders Charged In May 9 Attack Case
item.description: An Anti-Terrorism Court has indicted Pakistan's former Prime Minister Imran Khan and other Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) leaders in connection with the May 9 attack on the General Headquarters (GHQ) in 2023.

item.title: Clean Energy Program Races to Finish Work Before Trump Takes Over
item.description: The Energy Department’s $400 billion program to support electric vehicles, batteries and other low emissions technology is hustling to get money out the door.

item.title: South Korea’s Martial Law Declaration Stirs Memories in Gwangju
item.description: The last time South Korea imposed martial law, Gwangju endured a deadly crackdown. Han Kang, the Nobel Prize-winning author, told its story in “Human Acts.”

item.title: The V.I.P. Trains Shuttling World Leaders Like Biden to War-Torn Ukraine
item.description: With airspace closed and missiles flying, visiting Kyiv typically means 10 hours on bumpy tracks — even for presidents, prime ministers and business magnates. It’s plenty of time to reflect.

item.title: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer Is Fighting Populism From the Lonely Center Ground
item.description: One of the last centrist leaders left on the global stage, Prime Minister Keir Starmer this week outlined his plan to deliver change for people in the U.K. Will it be enough?

item.title: South Korean President, Yoon Suk Yeol, Faces Impeachment Call from Own Party Leader
item.description: The leader of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party has backed impeachment, on which the National Assembly is set to vote on Saturday.

item.title: Turkey, Iran and Russia to meet in Doha on Saturday to discuss Syria, Turkish source says
item.description: Foreign ministers from Turkey, Iran, and Russia are set to convene in Doha this Saturday to address the recent surge by Syrian rebels. The rebels have achieved significant territorial gains, capturing Aleppo and Hama.

item.title: Iran conducts successful space launch in program long criticised by West
item.description: Iran launched a satellite-carrying rocket using its Simorgh program, a move the West believes bolsters its missile technology. This launch, amidst heightened Middle East tensions, comes after the expiration of UN missile sanctions. While Iran insists on peaceful intentions, concerns remain about its nuclear capabilities and past military nuclear program.

item.title: 'Division is one of the greatest challenges of our time,' says Barack Obama at democracy forum
item.description: Former President Barack Obama addressed divisiveness in his first post-election speech, calling it a major challenge. He emphasized the importance of building alliances and coalitions for lasting change, even with those holding differing views. Obama acknowledged limits to compromise when fundamental justice is threatened, citing historical figures who championed pluralism. He urged collaborative action for a more just society.

item.title: Canada gun ban: Additional 324 military-style firearms barred, explores donation to Ukraine amid growing tensions
item.description: Canada banned 324 additional firearm models deemed more suitable for warfare than sport or hunting, intending to donate some to Ukraine. This expands on a 2020 ban and includes an amnesty period for owners. The move, preceding the École Polytechnique tragedy's anniversary, aims to curb gun violence, but faces criticism for impacting licensed owners.

item.title: California governor Gavin Newsom calls Trump's tariffs on Mexico and Canada 'betrayal'
item.description: California Governor Gavin Newsom criticized President-elect Trump's proposed tariffs on Mexico and Canada, calling them a "betrayal" and harmful to California's economy. He highlighted the importance of cross-border trade and announced plans to bolster border security against fentanyl and illegal weapons while seeking funds for legal defense against potential lawsuits from the incoming Trump administration.

item.title: Elon Musk: The world’s richest man is now America’s biggest political donor
item.description: Elon Musk spent over $274 million in the 2024 election, primarily backing Donald Trump's successful presidential bid. His funding, channeled through America PAC, supported Trump's campaign activities and targeted advertising. Musk's significant investment made him the largest donor of the cycle, surpassing all others, and secured him a prominent advisory role in the incoming Trump administration.

item.title: US President-elect Donald Trump wins 'Patriot of the Year' award at Fox Nation event
item.description: At the Fox Nation Patriot Awards, Donald Trump received the "Patriot of the Year" award. He praised Fox and celebrated his election victory. The event honored various patriots, including veterans and first responders. Trump's increased public appearances signal a renewed relationship with Fox after previous tensions.

item.title: 'Biden admin is trying to leave Trump as bad legacy as it can': Russia
item.description: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov accused the Biden administration of escalating the Ukraine conflict to hinder the Trump administration. Lavrov claimed the US might shift focus to other matters, leaving Europe to deal with Ukraine.

item.title: US President-elect Donald Trump picks David Perdue as Ambassador to China
item.description: Former Senator David Perdue has been nominated by President Trump as the next US Ambassador to China. Trump emphasized Perdue's extensive business background, Senate experience, and familiarity with Asia. Perdue expressed honor and readiness to implement Trump's strategy for global peace and represent US interests in China.

item.title: 'Trump is very strong person but is not pro-Russian': Russia's foreign minister Sergei Lavrov
item.description: Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov praised former US President Donald Trump's strong personality and straightforward approach, dismissing claims of Trump being a Russian ally. Lavrov highlighted the substantial sanctions imposed on Russia during Trump's presidency. He acknowledged Trump's directness and efficiency, emphasizing his respect for the American people's choice.

item.title: 'Russia ready to use any means to defend itself': Foreign minister Sergei Lavrov
item.description: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov warned the US that Russia is prepared to use "any means" to defend itself, including hypersonic weapons. This follows the recent use of the Oreshnik missile in Ukraine. Lavrov emphasized Russia's commitment to protecting its interests and people against Western exploitation of resources.

item.title: Marles rejects Netanyahu’s criticism of Australian government’s UN vote on Palestine
item.description:
Anthony Albanese notes 157 countries voted in favour of a Palestinian state, and that former Howard government held a similar position

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Australia’s defence minister, Richard Marles, has rejected Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s claims that Australia supporting a United Nations motion in favour of a Palestinian state would lead to more terrorism or antisemitism, saying the government remained a close friend of Israel.

The Coalition opposition has again accused Labor of changing its foreign policy, calling it an effort to chase votes in western Sydney. Former Liberal prime minister Scott Morrison called Labor’s decision “shameful” and accused the government of having “betrayed freedom”.

Sign up for Guardian Australia’s breaking news email

Continue reading...

item.title: Middle East crisis live: thousands of people flee Homs in central Syria as rebel forces push on
item.description:
Rebels have captured key cities of Aleppo and Hama, dealing blows to president Bashar al-Assad 14 years after protests erupted across Syria

The escalation in fighting in Syria has displaced about 280,000 people in just over a week, the UN said on Friday, warning that numbers could rise to 1.5 million.

“The figure we have in front of us is 280,000 people since 27 November,” Samer AbdelJaber, head of emergency coordination at the UN’s World Food Programme (WFP), told reporters in Geneva. “That does not include the figure of people who fled from Lebanon during the recent escalations” in fighting there, he added.

Continue reading...

item.title: Starmer vows to take on ‘blockers’ as Labour council says government housebuilding targets ‘impossible’ – UK politics live
item.description:
The PM has said he wants 1.5 million homes to be built in England before the next election

In his interviews this morning Keir Starmer stressed that improving public services would take time. He said he would not get everything done by Christmas. (See 9.36am.)

But Starmer also suggested that people would see their living standards rise “straight away”. Rejecting claims that things might get worse before they get better, he told BBC Breakfast:

I want people to feel better off straight away – feel better off in the sense of more money in their pocket, feel better off because they’ve got a secure job that they know is guaranteed to give them the money they need.

I want others to feel the difference as quickly as possible.

Continue reading...

item.title: Don’t expect better public services ‘by Christmas’, Starmer says
item.description:
Prime minister says problems in health, housing and education will take years to rebuild

• UK politics live – latest updates

Keir Starmer has told voters not to expect rapid public service improvements as he seeks to relaunch his faltering government withlong-term targets on housebuilding, living standards, energy, policing, education and the NHS.

In broadcast interviews on Friday morning, the prime minister said he could not promise immediate change, blaming the previous Conservative government for leaving behind problems which could take years to solve.

Continue reading...

Syrian rebel leader urges Iraq to keep Hashd al-Shaabi factions out of Syria
Russia's Rosneft invested $20 billion in India, Indian government quotes Putin as saying
Johnson rejects Biden request for $24 billion on new Ukraine aid
Israel showed the 'power' of F-35s in destroying nearly all of Iran's air defenses without a loss, UK admiral says
Suddenly, Trump’s Ugliest Threats Are Facing Surprise GOP Resistance
